EDUCATIONAL TELEVISION STATIONS
A division of
NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTERS
PHONE: 667-6000 • 1346 CONNECTICUT AVENUE • WASHINGTON, D.C. 20036
July 9, 1968
Mrs. Elinor K. Wolf
Coordinator for Citizen Participation
400 Maryland Avenue, Room 4111
Washington, D. C. 80202
Dear Mrs. Wolfs
Thank you for giving me the opportunity to meet with
you and William Whalen in your office this week. It is my con¬
viction that educational radio and television must play an
important part in your responsibility to involve the com¬
munity in education and I mean to do all we can to assist you.
Commissioner Howe'# memorandum to chief state
school officers on involving the community In the Elementary,
Secondary Education Act seems to me something we ought to
put before all of the educational broadcasters in the nation.
There are many ways in which they could be of value in
carrying forward these objectives in each of their commu-
ities. For this purpose, we would like to request 400 copies
of that memorandum in order that we may distribute it to all
stations. I’d appreciate it therefore if you could supply these
to me.
As I look at the request that each community form
its own committee, it occurs to me that it would be logical to
assume a national committee might evolve from these many
local committees. Is this a possibility? If so, lean see
educational broadcasting feeing put to good use nationally to
carry forward the objectives of such a national committee.
Thank you for giving me your copy of "Tell It Like It
Is. M I think this would make an excellent television presenta¬
tion and intend to pursue that development.
Incidentally, I don't want us to forget the possibility
of repeating the school TY series, HQae Nation Indivisible. "
